title: Gloria Steinem, 85, says critics STILL dismiss her as 'just a Playboy bunny'
text:
Gloria Steinem has racked up countless achievements during her 85 years, but she says even today some people will still dismiss her as 'just a Playboy bunny.'

The feminist activist famously went undercover at the New York Playboy Club in 1963 and wrote a scathing exposé about the experience.

But the journalistic gig has been latched onto by critics as a means to scoff at her, and she told People this week, 'To this day, as old as I am, especially when there’s an urge to be diminishing in some way, people will say, "Oh well, she was just a Playboy bunny."'

Icon: Gloria Steinem has racked up countless achievements during her 85 years, but she says even today some people will still dismiss her as 'just a Playboy bunny'

Undercover: The feminist activist famously went undercover at the New York Playboy Club in 1963 and wrote a scathing exposé about the experience

Steinem said that it seems that some of these people either forgot or don't realize that she wasn't actually working as a Playboy bunny, but rather was a journalist going undercover to expose the process of becoming one, as well as the working conditions.

In fact, the piece she wrote — 'A Bunny’s Tale' for Show Magazine — made a difference for the women.

'It actually improved the working conditions, which were unspeakable.'

The former Ms. Magazine editor — whose new book, The Truth Will Set You Free, But First It Will Piss You Off!, comes out Oct. 29 — also revealed that after publishing, other bunnies reached out to 'warn' her.

'They couldn’t believe that I had written this exposé because they thought it was dangerous. And my name was in the phone book,' she said.

Late husband: Steinem also opens up about her marriage to David Bale, whom she wed in 2000 at the age of 66

'I thought, "Well, we worked 30 years to change the marriage laws,"' she said. 'I wouldn’t lose my name, my credit rating, my legal domicile, all the things I would’ve lost before we worked to change the marriage laws' (pictured in 1972)

In the new issue of People, Steinem also opens up about her marriage to David Bale, whom she wed in 2000 at the age of 66.

'I thought, "Well, we worked 30 years to change the marriage laws,"' she said. 'I wouldn’t lose my name, my credit rating, my legal domicile, all the things I would’ve lost before we worked to change the marriage laws.'

She married South African-born Bale, whom she says she loved, in part to help him get a green card.

The entrepreneur, who is also father to actor Christian Bale, died three years later.
description: The feminist leader famously went undercover at the New York Playboy Club in 1963. Her piece, A Bunny's Tale' for Show Magazine, helped changed working conditions.
